text: Pitch black color with small white head. Alcohol, caramelized sugar, wood and fig aroma. Sweet chocolate, alcohol, alcohol candy, wooden barrel taste. Medium to full body, soft carbonation. Awesome.
Bottle at home. Taste is sweet, malty and roasted. Dried fruits and wood. Very nice mouthfeel. One of the better clean scotch ale!
Dosyć mocno naładowane słodami - karmel, czekolada, typowe Scotach Ale. Niby wszystko na miejscu, zgodnie ze stylem, ale bez fajerwerków. W tle lekkie nuty dymione.

650ml bottle from Beergium. Dark brown, cola coloured beer with very small and quickly vanishing head. Aroma has strong flavors of dark malts, bread, raisins and ripe fruits; plum mostly. Taste has malts, caramel, raisins, some ripe fruits and warming alchocol & sugar at the end. Moderate sweetness, medium carbonation and body. Reminds me a bit of stronger Belgium ales. Quite good.
Solid, very well made beer. Was expecting a bit more from Cigar, but still - its good enough.

Bottle shared @Pułapka, Gdańsk
Fruity butterscotch aroma. Taste is sweet and malty, very smooth with a bit of alcohol coming out just before the finish. Caramel finish

Bottled. small sample. The aroma has toffee, caramel, bit horseblanket, roast. Brown coloured beer with an off-white-beige head. The taste is sweet toasted malty, with fruitiness, horseblanket, cookies, molasses. Ends more bitter. Good.
Bottle @ Bibere, Piraeus. Color dark brown with small head. Aroma hoppy, roasted, malt, caramel. Taste sweet, caramel, hoppy, alcohol, fruits.

Dark mahogany color with light brown head. Aroma has intense dark fruits like dates and dried cherries. Taste starts also fruity with a hint of burnt sugar. Finishes really balanced. Medium body and carbonation. Overall its a nice scotch ale, true to style and really well made.

Bottle, 650 ml from Beergium. Shared with rest at the grand tasting 11/2016. Pours dark brown with small tan head. Average to heavy malty, roasty, caramel, some dark fruit, nutty. Moderate sweetness, medium bodied.
Bottle. Dark brown pour with tan head. Roasted, earthy, light fruity and herbal aromas. Flavors are earthy, fruity, herbal tones.
Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupełniania profilu na ratebeer. CBC #86. Zaskakująco płaskie i nijakie, spore rozczarowanie.

660ml bottle - thanks martjoobolut!
Nice sweet belgian strong ale aroma, tons of esters here. Taste very similar, but a bit of maple syruppy sweetness. Dryness in finish, woody, and nutty.

Bottle (from beergium). Pours dark brown. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruits, raisins. Flavor is sweet and bitter, caramel, burnt sugar, fruits, raisins, malt. Finish is malty. Covers alcohol well. Overall: very good..

1 pint bottle, shared by Mart, thanks! Brown beer, tan head. Nose is caramel and malt, raisins, bready notes. Flavor is sweet and malty, bread crust, caramel and more malt, dark fruit and raisins. Lovely malt character.

sample from bottle, poured a murky brown colour with a tanned head. nose of caramel malts, big raisins, sticky toffee notes, earth, dried plums, light mocha coffee notes, dried red fruits, nose sweet malts finish.

On tap at CCB airport brew pub. Pours a translucent, light brown caramel color with little head. Nose is rich malt, caramel and toffee. Slight hints of dark fruit. Taste follows with a great mouth feel. Very good scotch ale.

bottle. This years release. Brown into deep red with a small head with full of lacing. Aroma is malts, caramel, slight toffee, slight raisins, slight dark fruits. Full bodied on the tongue, very rich with a somewhat sticky sweet finish.

750ml bottle. 1/12/16 bottle date. Appearance: Deep brown with ruby red hints and relatively clear. Low lying khaki colored head dissipates quickly. 
Aroma: Rich caramel maltiness, with dark cherry and plum notes. Just a hint of roast and toasted bread.
Taste: Rich, sweet maltiness heavy on caramel, toffee, and bread crusts. Finished with a clean, balanced hop bitterness and a touch of dark cherry. 
Mouthfeel: Heavy bodied, with a low carbonation and a moderate alcohol warming. 
Finish: Leaves a rich lingering maltiness on the tongue, with some toasted bread and toffee
Overall: Top notch scotch ale. Strong aroma with lots of malt complexity with a range of caramel, toffee, toasted bread, and dark fruit flavors. Relatively easy drinking considering the ABV. Six months of age and this still has very strong flavors without being harsh and abrasive. Interested to see how this changes with some age.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2016 Bottle shared by masterofhoppets. Pours dark reddish brown with a medium brown head. Aromas of prunes, dates, chocolate, raisins, malt, caramel, light booze, cherries. Taste has lots of malt, caramel, sweet dark fruits. Lots of raisins, prunes, dates, rye bread, some anis, chocolate, subtle cherry like notes.
On tap @ CBC-16. Dark brown with a small tan head. Cruity and caramel tones. Fruit, malt, caramel and hops. Medium to full body with a bitter / fruity finish.

Draft at source. Strong caramel and deep toffee with some light raisin and fig notes. Smells like a rich maple syrup. Taste is just as decadent. Thick, viscous, but never cloying. Only a faint alcohol warming. Wow. Ive had this a lot and forgot how good this really is.

[5/13/16] Draught sample at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2016. Blue session. Dark brown. Aroma of caramel, dark fruits. Sweet flavor, caramelly, with dark fruits, nutty notes. Medium to full-bodied, quite rounded.

Sample @ CBC16, Copenhagen. Blue session. Clear bronze pour with a samll head. Notes of caramel, sweet malts, fudge and dark died fruits.

750ml bottle pours dark opaque chestnut brown with half finger of head. Nose is malty fruit, caramel, maple, wet leaves, cocoa, raisin. Taste is a touch thin up front with caramel, dark fruit, raisin, plum, maple, sticky and sweet. Finishes sweet, some decent creaminess on the tail end, lingering earthy maple and caramel, raisin.
On tap at CBC 2016. Dark caramel with a tan head. Caramel, dark fruit, dried fruit and cocoa. Excellent.
@Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2016, BLUEdark brown. Malty, bit bready, dark bready, slight herby nose. Full bodied, malty, some dry syrupy sweetness. Malts..-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
CBC2016. Trübes orange braunes Bier mit einer geringen beigen Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, Schokolade, süß. Geschmack nach roten Früchten, dunkles Malz, bourbon, Karamell.

Pours clear deep amber with small tan head. Sweet aroma of caramel, malt. Smooth, but missing some complexity.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap@ CBC 2016. Deep brown, thick off white head. Dark fruits, plums, bread, molasses. Flavor has dark bread, molasses, dark fruits. Balanced. Bit heavy.

Pours barely translucent ruby-mahogany with a thin buff head. Aroma delivers caramel, toasted malt and toffee tones. Flavor nicely echoes the aroma and adds a woody hint,vas well as candy sweetness but not too much. Firm, viscous mouthfeel is smooth but has some decent fizz. Make a big sound!
This is so good. Thanks Dchmela. Pours a thick dark mahogany. Aromas of coffee, dark fruit, bread, peat, a bit of smoke. Similar flavours. Thick, sweet and rich. So malty and delicious. Great stuff.

Bottle. Dark brown pour, robust head, and good aroma of malt with strong hints of caramel. Taste is sweet malt with some figs. Well balanced Scotch. Its all about the malt with this, hops are barely noticeable. Finishes sweet. Good Scotch. Thanks for sharing JB.

Brought this back from Florida. Luckily had wife along at Orlando store who asked if they had Cigar City - they pulled this from behind the counter. A few days later I went back, none left. it is syrupy, a bit more hops than the norm, but still, not super wonderful. I did enjoy the nose with the cherries along with the malty notes.

Deep mahogany pour that has rich garnet highlights under dense, mocha head.
Aroma of dark caramel and molasses.
The flavor has some caramel sweetness but isnt overly so. Some roast malt and a hint of licorice. 
Big bodied tasty sipper.
22oz bottle in Fl. Tasty. Positive Aroma. Cant really place specific flavors but generally great scotch ale.
Sweet aroma of toffee, roasty toasty malt and some fruit underneath. Taste is sweet with plenty bready malt, light nuts and finishes sweet and sticky. Good!
Brown color, little head, aromas and flavors of malt, caramel and a bit of dried fruits. Nice body
On draft at Cigar City Aug 2014. Black pour with medium brown tinge on the outsides; no head. Scotchy and syrupy flavor/texture. Plain good.

bomber shared poured a medium to dark brown color with off white head. the nose is sweet malt and hints of chocolate. so so nice. the flavor is very well balanced. the flavor almost has hints of dark fruit along with the sweet malts which is traditional for a scotch ale. really frigging good. long lasting sweetness on the tongue. now I need more of this one.

Bottle from 2012. Pours clear deep chestnut, small tan head, dissipates to a ring with decent lacing. Aroma is malty, dark sugars and coffee indeed dominate. Flavor is medium sweet, light plus bitter, hugely malty, toffee, toasted caramel, marshmallow, coffee, hint of chewing tobacco. Slice acidity bites at the sweetness a bit. Some dates and figs in there as well. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel. Some ABV burn on the finish. Pretty good beer.
Brown pour with hint of red and off white head. Aroma is nutty and musty. Taste is caramel malt. Great beer.

Brown pour clear and small tan head. Aroma of nutty malts. Flavor of dried nuts and some dried dark fruits. Really great style I need to divulge in more. I hear ale smith got a good one.....bottle trade?

Bottle, aroma of malts, bread, and caramel, taste of lots of caramel a touch nutty, real nice

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
It poured a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma was of malts, caramel and some fruit. The taste was of caramel malts, roast, cherries, some toffee, bread and a bit of smoke. Tasty.

It is a dark brown with some light that gets through. It has a brown head. The aroma has toffee and coffee with cherries on the second go around. It has flavors of toffee and coffee that are combined. There are bits of cherries in the flavor as well. It is sweet, with a warming alcohol finish.
This beer rocks. Slightly sweet finish plus a unique kick up front makes you know you are drinking a mans beer. A boozy wonderful taste but not all that boozy if that makes any sense.

Tasted from draft. Pours a dark brown with off white head. Sweet aroma with caramel, biscuits and syrup. Taste is moderate to heavily sweet. Dark fruits of raisins and plums, caramel, toffee, maple syrup, figs, biscuits, earthy flavors. Definitely one of the best scotch ales I've had. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at home. Pours deep brown, fruity cherry on nose. Sweet toffee, cherry almond taste.
Bottle at share, almost black, no head. Aroma raisin and fruit, toffee. Taste is huge raisin and plum, dark fruit, some roasted malt. Palate rich, carbonation subdued. Fairly sweet.
22iz bottle pours a hazy brown with an off white head. Caramel toffee and sweet malt taste.
Bottleshare thankd to DrewFace. Pours dark brown, tan head. Aroma of peaty stuff, sounds right. Taste is malty, smokey, peat, decent.

Great aroma of sweet fruit and smoke. The taste is excellent. Balances the sweetness of the malt and the stone fruit that comes with it, all washed away by the slight smokiness. Fine example of the style.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2016 "slight cherry my #$%! this was odd in a wat that only a few breweries can pull off. luckily for us, CC is one of them. Kind of a cross between a good, traditional scotch ale with dark fruit and hints of smoke, and Cuvee de Tomme with its cherry-twang thing going on. the fruitiness was not subtle in the aroma or flavor, as the label would have you beleive, but was quite enjoyable. I am now intrigued by the bourbon version of this brew..."
Dark brown to black with tan heAad. Very nice stout thin like carbonation. Big big rich malt and caramel. So silky smooth with slihjy alcohol warmth. This is such a wonderful brew. A++++

Well done. Nicely made scotch from CCB. Heavy malt aroma with plenty of caramel. Flavor is loads of roasted and caramel malt, chewy for sure. Mild bite from the alcohol but not crazy. Actually, its pretty damn drinkable

Bottle. Pours a deep dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, dark fruit, molasses and had a hint of smoke. Flavor was quite sweet with caramel, dried dark fruit, toffee, toasted malts, molasses and had some notes of chocolate. Full body, creamy texture, medium carbonation

750ml bottle purchased at Knightly Spirits in Orlando, Florida. Batch #3, Vintage 2010. Rich mahogany in colour with a long lasting beige coloured head, good lacing. Aroma is sweet, some toffee, lots of peat and earth, woody, dark fruits. Flavour is very peaty, some smoke, highly sweet, lots of caramel malts, dark fruits, christmas cake, burnt. Sweet mouthfeel, medium body, moderate carbonation. Finishes long, sweet, some smoke. Its alright but didnt have the punch that I was looking for. Meh.

This was so-so in my opinion. Malt aroma and flavor was to be expected, but I didnt grasp the depth of flavors. Maybe my taste buds were having an off day. Some caramel notes. Finish had bready malts without too much sweetness. Ho hum.

750 mL bottle. caramel brown with a small brown head. Brown sugar, nuts, and a little smoke in the nose. Theses notes carry through the flavour as well, where they are joined by some bread and a touch of booze. Great body. Very well constructed beer.

07.04.2014, 0,75l bottle @ BBGTC tasting:
Big fizzy shortlasting head. Aroma is slightly sour-ish fruity, caramel malts, dark fruits, grass, oak, sorrel, sugar, almond cake, butterscotch, chocolate. Taste is slightly sweet, caramel malts, grapes, dark fruits, sugar, butterscotch, grass, almond cake, chocolate, sorrel. Little bitterness, slightly harsh mouthfeel. Very boring!

Bottle, shared with BBGTC. Pours a deep brown body, small bubbly off-white head. Nose is mild oxidized port tones, caramel, toffee, hints of raisins, cereals and mild smoke. Taste is caramel, toffee, nougat, mild port tones, hints of nuts, vanilla and biscuits. Full body, medium to soft carbonation. Pretty nice, but not fantastic.

A- Pours a deep brownish hue with a small, coffee head which dissipates rather quickly.

S- Smell is very big, lots of caramel, hints of roasted malt, coffee and brown sugar.

T- Taste starts off with sweet, smooth caramel and leads into a bit of an acidic coffee flavor that ends very balanced.

M- Thick with carbonation on the high side of medium.

D- This seems like a hybrid of a scotch ale and an imperial stout to me. While scotch ales arent my favorite, this one got my attention and I enjoyed it.

Pours a dark ruby brown with a tan head. Aroma is awesome! Notes of toffee, caramel, and a touch of smokey malt and slight coffee. Taste is just as good as youre hoping for! Sweet malt, toffee, brown sugar, and wonderful roasty undertones. So smooth and drinkable. Delicious!

Bottle at OConnors, Uppsala, February 2014. 

Hazy dark reddish/brown with a tan head. Aroma and taste of chocolate, toffee, nuts and malt. Sweet with some warming alcohol in the finish.

750 ml bottle poured into a snifter. Pours a dark brown with a big khaki colored head of foam. The aroma has rich toffee and dark fruit notes. Some chocolate notes are there as well. The taste is more of that dark fruit and chocolate sweetness. Some sherry notes, perhaps. Big, chewy mouthfeel and body. Lower end of carbonation. Really good beer.

Poured from 750ml bottle into some weirdly shaped teardrop glass. At first sip, a lot to take in. It's candy sweet and complex and throws your tongue into a lot of different directions. Dark fruits and chocolate overlap with a subtle, deep booziness to produce an indulgent, yet coherent beer. It seems unwieldy at first, but never gets too sloppy or out of control. Nicely done. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Deep brown liquid with small to medium light tan head. Aroma of raw sugar, caramel, bread, port wine, toffee, dried fruit and sweet alcohol. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with notes of raw sugar, caramel and dried fruit. Medium to full bodied with medium carbonation. Nice

Bachelor party scotch ale tasting. 750 mL bottle courtesy of Chris, served in a stem glass alongside the bourbon barrel-aged version. Pours deep chestnut with a small tan head that fades to a thin remnant. The nose has loads of molasses, brown sugar, toasted malts, herbs and subtle earthy hops. The flavour is moderately sweet with toasted malts, caramel, and molasses, along with raisins and a subtle dose of hops. The finish is long, toasty and malty with subtle hops. On the palate, it is full in body with a smooth, creamy texture. Overall, this is a truly great scotch ale with beautiful toasted malts. 2013-07-25

More fun from the cellar of the Porter. Pours black with minimal head. Candy and booze are all over the nose. Boozy and sweet flavors are magnified by the oozing thickness of this brew. Delicious. Bottle - The Porter - Atlanta, GA

Bottle shared with Zach at Bash in Sunrise, FL. Snifter. Pours a deep brown with a one finger foamy head. Great lacing and the crown stayed in place. The aroma was strong with coffee, cherry, malts and booze. The taste starts with coffee, heavy malts and transitions into a smooth booze -like toffee. I didnt really get the cherry as noted in the description but it did seem to have a soft fruitiness. Full body, slightly oily. Better as it warmed. Finish is not overwhelming booze.
22 ounce bottle from the beer broker, carmelly, bready, dry on the tounge. Goes well with turkey.
Bottle from trade quite a while ago. Aroma and flavors of big malt, molasses, some caramel, pumpkin-type bread, etc. Hardly a bit of hops detected, this is a superb malt bomb. Great beer.
Copper with a thin tan head. Sweet aroma of toffee, roasty toasty malt and some fruit underneath. Taste is sweet with plenty of toffee, bready malt, light nuts and finishes sweet and sticky.

A: Dark Opaque Hue, Passes No Light, Off White Head Ring, No Lacing

S: Dark Malts, Caramel, Toffee, Mild Chocolate

T: Dark Chocolate Malts, Caramel, Toffee

M: Mediocre Carbonation, Medium to Full Bodied, Mildly Sweet

Overall, a really great scotch ale with accentuated flavors on cask.
Pours a deep dark brown/black color with big tan head. Aroma of dark malt, dark fruits. Flavor of caramel, dark fruits, plum, and a slight bit of roastiness. Very tasty scotch ale.

Pours imperial stout dark with mahogany on the edges and a small tan head. Smells malty, caramel, and hints of fruit. Taste is sweet caramel and dark fruits. Full-bodied with a slick texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Cigar City Big Sound Scotch Ale finishes with a touch of sweetness and a hint of smoke.

Bottle 75 cl from erzbierschof.ch. Dark brown beer, heavy and with a small head. Aromas of caramel-molasses, black cherries, roasted. The body is full, a bit sticking. The mouth is syrupy, with black cherries, chocolate-coffee, roasted and point of butter. There is also hints of prune, fig and alcohol. Low bitter, sweetened finale, spiced and toasted. A warm beer.

750ml bottle. Pours a very dark, deep ruby red color with a light tan, one finger head that has decent retention. The aroma was of caramel, toast, toffee, earthy hops, sweet raisins, a touch of spice like cinnamon. Taste is similar to the aroma with some caramel, dates, and nutty malts upfront, followed by toasted malts, toffee, some bitterness and dryness in the finish. Full bodied with low to medium carbonation.

Bottle from the brewery dated 9/11/13. Pours a deep dark brown with a khaki yellow brown head. Verrrrry slight ruby on the edges but mostly opaque. Aroma of sweet molasses, chocolate, roast, smoke, toffee, biscuits, and more chocolate. Flavor is a nice roasty smokey chocolate with a lingering peaty flavor on the palate. Sweet molasses takes over the palate after chocolate subsides up front. Rich and creamy but with offsetting light carbonation and not stout heavy. Good scotch ale ad can see how this would take on the bourbon barrels well. Will have to find the BA version this season.

Dark brown pour, tan head. Aroma is toffee, molasses, has some interesting coffee notes. Flavor is similar. Slightly sweet with some really nice toffee character adn some dark fruit hiding in the back. Good beer.

Pours deep deep amber with a huge pillowy beige head. 

Smell is caramel and red fruit. Getting some tartness too, but I might be crazy. 

Taste is very smooth for 9%, grain and caramel sweetness. Leaves a tiny bit of roast on the aftertaste.

Lively, well carbonated, smooth. 

Solid
My first scotch ale...then many more came. Bread, resin, earthy, woody...drinking sand...of the highlands. Only tried once, when I wasn´t so recpetive to the style.
Gedronken @ RBESG 13 Grand Tasting, zwart/bruine kleur, bruine schuimkraag, ruikt zoet, fruitig, framboos, beetje kruidig en smaakt ook zo, er is wel veel koolzuur aanwezig

Pours dark brown from a 500 cc bottle. Light brown head, quickly fading. Aroma is sweet malt, raisin, and spice. Flavour is rich sweet malts up front, molasses, vanilla, nice smooth astringent finish from light hops. Awesome Scotch Ale.

Dark brown colour, beige head. Aroma of caramel, malts, fruity, light sour berries. Sweet flavour, caramel, cherry, sour touch, malts. Finish cherry, malts, berries, light sour. One of the better Scotch ales, Id say (though Im not a big fan of the style)
(From 75cL bottle @ RBESG 2013 Grand Tasting, Bodegraven. Thanks for sharing, joes!)
Bottle. Dark brown beer with a beige head. Smokey, tar and fruity aroma. Ashes, tar, a bit salty and fruity, malty flavour. A really nice beer :-)

Sampled @ RBESG 13 Grand Tasting. Opaque brown colour with some particles (chunks), small beige head. Smells sourish, rubberish, herbs, spices and a bit peppery. Tastes sourish, fruity, lots of herbs and spices. Medium body, medium carbo.

(bottle) pours a slightly hazy ruby-amber colour with a creamy off-white head. aroma of balsamic vinegar, tobacco, white grapes, roasted malts and caramel. flavour is mostly the same, slightly reminiscent of an oud bruin, with a medium sweetness, some bread dough, caramel and roasted malts. medium to heavy-bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle @ RBESG13 Grand Tasting @ De Molen: Served in a Molen taster: Thanks for sharing Joes:
Vanilla beige light brown colored foamy head that changes into some kind of lacing with regular speed. This Big Sound has a deep dark brown color.
Aroma is an interesting mix of caramel, brett/wild yeast, rye, bread, mocha and butter.
Flavours of roast, prunes, marzepin, cream, malt roast, raisin, light soap, bitter and some bready yeast.
Aftertaste is bitter, sweet, roast, chalkand dark sweet fruits.

text: 75 cl. bottle sampled @ RBESG 2013. Thx! to Joes. Dark brown, light ruby hue, little tanned head. Nose is red fruits, light caramel, thick berries, Schwarzwald pie. Taste is sweet berries, Schwarzwald pie, thick mocha, light port, sour notes, redd berries, bitter herbs & some spice. Thick body. Reminds me a bit of Kalevipoeg due to the Schwarzwald pie & berry notes. Another excellent CCB brew, confused by the low ratings to be honest.
Bottled @ RBESG 2013 Grand Tasting. Fruity, tart, spicy yeast, horseblanket. Bit sweet cookie. Its complex, but a bit unbalanced in all the flavors. Still I quite like it actually.
Bottle @ RBESG grand tasting. Dark red brown color, virtually no head. Smell and taste sweet-sourish, with sone alcohol and something weird. Hmm average body and carbonation. Dont really like it.
Donker roodbruinbier. Ruikt iets zurigs en wijn achtig. Smaakt zoetig bourban achtig.
Pours a nice dark brown beer with a good tan head. Smells weird. Vanilla and creamy. Dont like it. Bourbon likely.

Sample at CBC 2013.

Dark brown colour with a small off-white head. Aroma and flavour of fruit, caramel, wood, bourbon, yeast and malt.
Bottle @CBC13. Brown with small head. Aroma sweet with lots of malt, caramel, grain and hops. Flavor is sweet toasted malt, grain, wood, lots of caramel and grassy bitterness. Light to medium body

750ml bottle purchased at the brewery in Jan 2013.  Hazy, cola colored body with a thin, tan head.  Diminishes to a fine ring with moderate lacing.  Aroma contains vanilla, vague pitted fruit, and bread crust.  Not as rich as I expected.  Flavor brings much more: the above plus faint roast, plum, and fig.  A touch of caramel and toffee.  Full body, moderate carbonation.  Very malting with a tasty, lingering finish.  A very good sipper!

750 ml bottle into snifter, bottled on 8/20/2012.  Pours moderately cloudy very dark reddish brown color with a 1 finger dense cream colored head with good retention, that reduces to a thin lace cap that lingers.  Light soapy lacing clings on the glass.  Aromas of big caramel, molasses, raisin, cherry, apple, toast, pear, toffee, clove, light roast, peat smoke, dark bread, and toasted earthiness.  Fantastic aromas with great balance and big complexity of dark/toasted malt notes with fruitiness and moderate peat.  Taste of big caramel, molasses, raisin, cherry, apple, toast, toffee, pear, clove, light roast, dark bread, light peat, and toasted earthiness.  Lingering notes of caramel, molasses, light and dark fruit, toast, toffee, clove, dark bread, light roast, light peat, and earthiness on the finish for a while.  Damn nice balance with big complexity of malt and fruity flavors; with zero cloying sweetness after the finish.  Medium carbonation and very full bodied; with a slick, creamy, and lightly syrupy mouthfeel that is great.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a highly excellent scotch ale!  Very nice balance and big complexity of malt/fruity flavors; and very smooth to sip on.  A highly enjoyable offering.

gave this a lower rating than most b/c it was just too damn sweet to drink;   I did age this for 1.5 years.  aroma was of malt, sugar, and dark fruits.  hazy off bronw pour.  taste was similiar to aroma with 47 lbs. of burnt sugar - just tooooo rich and sweet.

Poured from a 750ml bottle into a chalice.

Appearance: Pours a dark cola brown with beautiful ruby red highlights and a 3 finger frothy medium tan colored head featuring tiny carbonation bubbles. Excellent creamy lacing coating the glass.

Smell: Tons of malt and cocoa with a touch of dried fruits. Smells a lot like Hersheys Whoppers.

Taste: Very sweet mix of flavors up front including cocoa and sweet malt with a touch of caramel up front followed by a light amount of hops in the middle and ending with lightly toasted malt at the finish. Aftertaste is mildly bittersweet and quite appealing. Very well-balanced beer that keeps the alcohol completely hidden.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied and creamy with a fairly high amount of prickly carbonation that gives it just about the perfect feel for me. Really coats the palate.

Drinkability: Excellent drinkability. The alcohol will sneak up on you since you really dont even notice that its there.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. Cigar City has really knocked it out of the park with this one. Ive liked just about every Scotch Ale/Wee Heavy that Ive tried and this one does nothing to change that. I would highly suggest trying this beer if you get the chance.

For over a year, Ive been trying to find ONE Scotch Ale that comes even close to the flavor and taste of McEwans Scotch Ale, which is on hiatus from being imported to the US. If you read my other reviews youll see Ive been through a LOT of them:
Wet Willys
Alesmith
Belhaven
Traquair House
Jolly Scott
Scotty Karate
Skullsplitter
Old Chub
Arcadia
Berkshire
French Broad
And more.

Ive liked some. Disliked others. NONE of them have the taste that McEwans brings to the table. I was dismayed and thought Id never get it again. I have a couple last bottles of Mac here that Id been saving. Ive been looking for some to trade in Canada where they apparently still exist, but its been rough.

So, after trying so many other SAs with nothing close (Alesmith was the closest and its a far jump) I halfheartedly opened a bottle of Big Sound last night.

Delightedly, I find that it aims squarely for the McEewans flavor and may even SURPASS it in every way. I went and read their web description. Cherries! Whod have thought? And heres me slamming every quad that sneaks freaking cherries into their blend!

So - if you like and miss McEwans - give this a try. I have a Mac opened and am going back and forth. Mac is definitely more soy sauce/tobbacco, while the BS is a bit sweeter - but its a fine line.
Heres the real BA rundown:

APP: Deep dark mahogany body with a beautiful full-figured head on top in vanilla caramel colors.

Smell: Molasses, Toffee, and apparently old cherries. I would have said English Fruitcake - but same thing.

Taste: Malt bomb, dark caramel syrupy sweet. Not too stouty, so a good drinker but really big flavor. Toffee, cherries, dark candied fruit, a little coffee, burnt sugar. Molasses. Wonderful.

Overall - just freaking amazing and an easy drinker.

Bottle share with a good friend. Big sound, big flavor. This brew was nice and dark with an earthy yet fruity flavor that had cherries and dark fruits coming out as the brew reached a nice temperature. Good enough to drink a few of while still being a complex brew.

Im quite lucky to be near this brewery. (I visited early 2010 and wasnt impressed with anything they had on tap beside the IPA, Ive been since an mostly everything is sound.

Bottle from the back of the cellar.  Got this about 18 months ago and kind of forgot about it.  I thought it might not be so good anymore, but I was wrong.  Pour is a deep, rich, syrupy brown with a thin but lasting blanket of tan foam.  Aroma is full of rich toffee malt, light alcohol, dark fruit, light autumn spice, and a touch of coffee and banana bread in the finish.  Flavor is also loaded with rich toffee malt, brown sugar, light molasses, notable alcohol, and a lightly spicy finish.  Kind of like a quad, barleywine mix.  Really tasty.  Maybe a bit hot, but still very good.

Bottle thanks to SoLan and his mom, thanks guys!  Pours a deep, ruddy reddish-brown color with a thin tan head that quickly receded to a ring.  Strong aroma of toffee, brown sugar, some apple fruitiness, a light roasted maltiness, and some vanilla.  Smooth, sweet entry with soft fruitiness (cherry, apple) that leads into a  sweet maltiness with hints of toffee, caramel, and brown sugar that lingered into the finish where it was met with a subtle roastiness that added a light dryness.  Low to no carbonation and slick, heavy mouth feel.  Overall, a pretty good tasting scotch ale that is really rich.  It tastes good, but almost becomes a chore to drink.  I also feared there was an infection problem upon initially smelling/tasting the beer, as there was an odd tartness present, but it seemed to disappear rather quickly.  This would be a nice drink on a cold night in smaller quantities.

Fløska. huge thanks to Plovmand for sharing! Dark amber-browm colour. Sweet vinious dark fruity aroma. Good filling mouthfeel. Sweet pleasant dark fruity vinious, dark malty flavour with spices. Well alsting sweet vinious dark fruity and malty finish. Qué sabor!

Bottle thanks to 50belair.  Deep reddish brown pour, thin fizzy off-white head.  Caramel, brown sugar, dark fruit, raisin, dried cherries, and toasted bread.  Very nice scotch ale.  Not quite as good as Alesmith wee heavy.

What a wonderful ale. I was given this and thought that jesus himself had come down from above and blessed me. Perfect harmony of sweet and caramel malts and a taste that really subdued any alcohol that was present. This is perhaps the best scotch ale I have tried. Even at 8.5% I feel that I could drink this for an entire night without caution. A great beer from Cigar City.

Let it be said instantly - This is without doubt the best beer with the disignation of "Scotch Ale" I have ever tasted. The pour is all brown with a cappochino colored head that allmost have an orange glow. The aroma is smokey caramel with both peaches and oranges and with a malty profile topped with some nice bitter notes. The taste is huge and as I said far more intens and interesting than other scotich ales I have had. I am thinking of those neat chocolates with Crand Marnier inside. A mild sourness somewhere far away. It has been malted with a fine bitterness and has a palate that tends to bite but at the same time heavy and fat with a long lasting sweet caramel-like finish. Good one
bottle - dark creamy and sour. toffee and caramel malts, a touch of soy, molasses and brown sugar. A bit sweet, even for a scotch ale.

Botlle. Courtesy of Hopscotch!!! It pours dark reddish brown with a medium off white head. The aroma is sweet malty, lots of caramel, light spices and dark fruit. Toasted caramel, light roasted malt, dark fruity notes and some raisins and prune. Lovely!!!

Medium sized tan head, good retention and lacing. Clear mahogany color. Nose of sweet malts, grain and dark fruits. Med/full body, oily on the palate. Plenty of sweet malts to go around. Caramel, light roast, earthy notes. Grainy, bready, little smoke. Sweet finish thats too long for me. Never was a Scotch Ale fan. Just too sweet for me. Guess if iwas rating to style it,d get a 4. But i aint ,,sooooo, Props to Bierbauch for the bottle!

Bottle.  Pours a very dark chestnut brown with a dark tan head.  Excellent lacing along the glass.  Wow, this one is good.  This one has a ton of different flavors coming together to form a delicious beer.  Very nice.

bottle.  a bit over a year old.   pours a clear dark brown  with some light ruby highlights, small dirty white head.   aroma of peat, smoke, maple syrup, and light cherry medicine.  taste is smokey, peat , milk dudes, and some light booze.  good beer.  lot goin on, and can see this being better fresh.  think i like the bourbon barrel version best, as it hid some of the medicinal notes i didnt care for in the original.  but liked this better than the apple brandy version or whatever.   medicinal yeasty note became more noticeable as it warmed.  okay

The aroma has a malty sweetness and a tad bit of smokiness. The dark oil appearance has a decent creamy tan head. The flavor of a smooth malty sweetness that settles so smoothly on the palate that you want to go back to a sip right away after tasting it. You can even taste that sweetness on your lips.

Bottle thanks to Beerlando! Poured a hazy dark brown with a gray brown head that lasted throughout the beer. Aroma is sweet with grains and toffee and underlying spice and dark fruits. Flavor is similar with sweet grains and toffee with a dark fruit finish and spice underlying. The aftertaste was a bit unsettling.

Pours a nice deep copper red with a light tan, retentive head. Brown sugar and wet grain aroma. Medium bodied with soft to average carbonation. Flavor or darker caramel malts, maple, wet grains. Moderate residual sweetness. Light citrusy tang on the finish, which was different.

Pours a muddy brown with tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, molasses, soy sauce, some ripe fruit.  Similar taste, very warming like a nice bourbon.  Sticky, almost cloying mouthfeel.  A bit sweet, but I guess thats par for the course for this style.

Pours dark brown with a decent enough head. Smells of scotch, bourbon, whiskey, roasted grains, rye bread, dark toffee and candy. Molasses and syrup. Tastes sweet but not cloyingly so. Nice mellow candy. Smores. Definitely some roasted marshmellow. Pretty nice considering the sweetness level.
Pours a great tan head with a brown body.  Aromas of brown sugar, note of iodine and soy.  Flavor is roasted malt, brown sugar, soy.  Finish is sticky, dark sweetness, good body.

Scotch Ale isnt really my favorite style, though there are a few that I like quite well.  I count Big Sound among the better group, but its still a bit too sweet and sticky for me.  The flavors are nice, though.  Big caramel, toffee and molasses.  Maybe a hint of some fruitier notes, like apricot, and maybe some smoke but not enough to make an impact.  Round feel, though it finishes kinda sticky.  Good enough beer, just sweet.  I tend to compare every Scotch Ale to AleSmiths Wee Heavy, and this beer doesnt hold up to that one.  However, its still among the best Scotch Ales Ive tried.

0.75 l bottle at Petalax Beer Festival 2010. Mahagony color. Sweet dessert wine like aroma with raisins, prunes and nuts. Worty, toffeish, nutty and raisiny flavor with some sharp alcohol. Thick full body. Nice aroma but the flavor is too worty and sharp.

Nice deep brownish pour, peaty earthed aromas come whispering off the top with some lite pined apples.  The chewy body is well nuanced but rather scattered with a lot of different flavors that just seem to be meeting each other.  Still it has a solid amount of depth and warmth.  Easy to drink for the style and another quality brew from these guys.

750ml. Bottle. Courtesy of peteinSD.  After all the hype regarding this brewery I was glad to get my hands on one of these. Poured a cloudy chocolate color with a persistent brown froth.  Nose was huge on malt with a small cherry character and maybe a little bit of mineral aroma.  Fantastic flavor with a complex malt profile. Has notes of sweet toffee, cocoa, overripe fruits and a little bit of smoke.  Shows a little bit of peat in the background, but nothing over the top.  The palate has a thick but non syrupy texture that suits the style well. Carbonation is present throughout, but never in the way.  The finish is relatively clean and ends with a sweet malt note.  Really nice take on a strong scotch. Makes me wish that more brewers were into the Scotch Ale style.

Bottle thanks to Andrew.    Brown red pour with a beige creamy head   Raisins dark fruit sweet sugars ash malty nice in the aroma. Charred red fruit caramel sweet fruit flavors. Malt sweet. Solid.  8/4/7/3/15

750 mL thanks to BierBauch via trade.   Pours a rich, deep nut brown, with a large, pillowy foam head.   Aroma is nutty and bitter, but very faint through all that foam.  Taste is suited to the nose, with the early palate bringing a full, nutty, almond bitterness, followed by a sweet malty caramel, accompanied by soy sauce.  There is a faint metallic taste to the finish, but over all, this is good, especially for a style I dont typically enjoy too much.  The early bitterness, balanced by the mid-to-late sweetness is just great.  There is even a touch of bread and coffee in this brew, as far as I can tell.  Excellent stuff.  Thanks Ron!

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2010 Pours a dark muddy brown, almost cola color with tan head. Nose is molasses, caramel, brown sugar and toffee. Taste is thick caramel butterscotch candy, toffee, sticky molasses and brown sugars.
Thanks drowland!  Pours very dark and has aroma of malt, chocolate and alcohol, flavor is some what boozy but is still delicious!

Opaque mahogany, pillowy thick tan head, creamy full body, necessarily high co2.

Aroma: lots of sweet roasted coffee malt, some laefy hops.

Taste: toffee, coffee, lots of dark cherry fruit, notes of highly caramelized / slightly burnt sugars.

Very full and sweet. Darker and more RIS than most Scotch Ales. Cloying if more than 12oz.

Bottle. Dark amber color, somewhat hazy, with a rich beige head. Earthy aroma, licorice, milk, malt. Hoppy citrus flavor, spicy, metal notes, smoky, salmiak, salt, some alcohol, cherry notes, roasted. Roasted spicy finish.
Bottle pours a dark red/brown with a thick foamy tan head. Scent is malts caramel and a hint of booze. Taste is sweet caramel and some fruit. Nice and I am glad I have more for the winter.

Bottle. Moderate to heavy malt aromas of toasted and dark chocolate, moderate hops and yeast notes of herbs and earth, with loads of raisin, tar, soy sauce dark brown sugar and toasted cocnut in the background. Head is average size, frothy, light brown with good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is dark brown. Flavor starts moderately to heavily sweet and lightyl acidic, then the long finish is lightly acidic moderately bitter and a touch sour. Palate is medium to full, creamy with a lively carbonation and a moderately alcoholic  and sticky finish. Probably the richest and fullest Scotch Ale Ive had. This is and excellent beer to be enjoyed slowly.

Thanks Grant for the treat. Pored this one into a large snifter sitting by a camp fire. I must say it may have influenced my score some by adding to the experience I even lit up a Liga Privada no.9 for my second glass which paired prefect in my book. The brew had a tan colored head on top of a dark brown body, and the head lasted leaving great lacing on the side of the glass.

Big roasted malt aromas come from this brew, so you get some coffee espresso notes. Now It might have been the campfire but I did get a slight hint of smoke LOL. It had a medium to light body. I wished for a tad more probably my only knock on the brew. 

The flavor was great, it had a healthy amount of sweet caramel malts to me with the right amount of roasted bitters to keep this brew well balanced. Again I did get some smokiness to it as well, but like I said the atmosphere enhanced this one. 

A great scotch ale well worth the effort to obtain. The drinkability was off the charts for me. I would love another bottle (hint)

750ml bottle from Secret Santa. Pours a cloudy brown color with a small beige head that soon fades to a fine ring. The aroma is somewhat faint almonds, figs, sweet malts and something earthy. The flavor is overtly sweet with toffee, light molasses, pecans, hazelnuts and dust. The palate is full and malty smooth, the carbonation is soft. Finishes long with lingering earthy nuts. Overall: Its quite good, but as it turns out its just a bit too sweet for me.  Im very grateful for the chance to try it, thanks santa.

750 ml bottle via trade with smith4498 - Pours a brown color with a 3/4 finger thick light tan head.  Light spotty lacing.  Aroma is toasted malt and esters.  Flavor is much of the same.  Medium body.  A nice beer.  Thanks Jason.

750 ml bottle from markwise- thanks again, Mark!  Pours a dark, cloudy chestnut brown color with some deep reddish tints and a small beige head that does not last.  Aroma of Scotch, dark fruits (dates, cherries, plums), earth, caramel malts, peat, and a little smoked meat.  Flavor of Scotch, the same dark fruits as in the nose, caramel malts, peat, chocolate, nuts, and alcohol.  The 8.5% ABV is definitely apparent throughout.  Medium-bodied, with medium carbonation and a fruity, peaty mouthfeel.  Nice Scotch ale.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2011 750 ml bottle from whole foods. Pours a dark brown with a thick tan head. Wonderful looking beer. Aroma is roasted malt, caramel, dark fruits and a bit of chocolate. Taste is caramel malty goodness, some molasses at the backend but overall very good. Palate, a bit too much carbonation, medium mouthfeel, alcohol doesnt warm you up too much. not as good as i remembered it

Pours a murky brown color with a thin light brown head. Aroma of caramel, peat and resinous hops. Very good flavor of peaty, earthy, roasted malt with caramel and resinous hops. The body is light to medium with a liquorous texture and soft carbonation. Good stuff.

Bottled @PBF2010 (thanks Joey Redner!). Ruby colour, small brown  head.Aroma is fruits, wood, some alcohol and quite sweet overall. Flavour is quite sweet, but still has some nuts, syrup, wood, fruits and quite a hard edge to it.

Bottled (PBF)
Dark nut brown color, decent steady beige head. Aroma has raisins, cellar and wood. Lots of alcohol, raisins, licorice, toffee. Long warming aftertaste. Strong Scotch Ale.

In short: A smooth, creamy and easy to drink peaty dark strong ale.  Very nice
How: Bottle 750ml.  Consumed when about 1 year of age.  Sent to me by Solan, thanks a lot Alan
The look: Chestnut brown body topped by a medium tan head with medium retention
In long: Nose has peaty earthy malts, light-medium smoky.  Taste is eat, tobacco leaves, caramel, birch, milk chocolate, dates, oily cashews, vinous notes.  I could go on.  The beer is not intense but with every sip I noted a little something else.  Overall the beer is smooth and pleasantly not too sweet for a Scotch Ale.  A scotch ale is usually something I get tired of when I drink a full bottle by myself.  But this one is rather sessionnable for the style.  Not the caramel/toffee lovefest that too many scotch ales are.  Interesting take on the style.  Another solid beer from Cigar City.  That brewery may be a bit over-hyped but they really put out quality beer after quality beer.  Surprisingly I have never been to Florida in my life.  Never.  I wanted to go one winter to enjoy the beaches and attractions.  And now with Cigar Cigar down there I will be able to complete my list of The Three Things I Have Done That Have Nothing To Do With Beer.

In the bottle from Leukens Liquors. Pours dark brown with a huge dark beige head. Intense peat and caramel to the aroma. The flavor consists of a super thick maltiness with strong dark caramels, a splash of smoked peat, and a dram of single malt whiskey. This is quite toasted at the finish. This is an incredible beer, but falls just shy of being legendary.

750ml bottle from Tsotsi.  Pours a dark copper, penny color with ruby hues.  Thick, frothy, light brown head with excellent lacing.  Aroma is very sweet and a little spicy.  There is a decent amount of alcohol coming through on the nose but nothing overpowering.  Taste is sweet and malty, very good.  Palate is very chewy and sticky.  Very thick and it sticks around for a while.  I really enjoyed this beer a lot.

24-06-10: Brune foncée avec reflets rougeâtres. Mousse beige, riche et persistante. Arômes de caramel, de malt, de toffe et de noix. Faible au palais, mais gagne en saveurs en bouche et en finale. Gout classique dune scotch ale, caramel, riche et sucrée, noisettes, toffe. Je mattendais, par contre, à un peu plus pour ma première cigar city beer.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle. 

The beer pours a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is caramel and toffee malt with some smoke and chocolate. I also get some woody and oak notes even though the beer is not barrel aged as far as I know. The flavor is heavy on the milk chocolate with some light smoke and toffee. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. One of the better Scotch Ales I have tried.

Definitely my kind of scotch. Nice and malty, sweet, hint of smoke and alcohol. Sweet toffee and cream, great mouthfeel and full body. A fair amount of balance with hops and grain with a hint of fruit. A bit of roasted malts round it out. Nice.

(bottle - 750 ml) Dark copper pour with a dark almost orange head. Heavy sweet and malty aroma with some very mild roasted notes. Some toffee and caramel as well. Flavor begins very sweet and malty. Tons of caramel and toffee flavors move smoothly to a malty and lightly toasted middle. Some light smoke comes through at the finish with a lingering and fruity sweetness. Big malt bomb but really good flavor and just the perfect amount of smoked malts.

Cola colored, thin white head. Cherry, chocolate, and bourbon in the nose, more definite malt and earthy grain in the flavor with a lasting heat. Long malty finish with dry cocoa. Controlled for CCB, the malt nicely balanced here without an overabundance of sweetness but the nose could definitely use more integration.

750 mL bottle. Pours a very dark brown, almost to the point of blackness, with a sturdy beige head. The aroma is raisin, vanilla, a hint of cocoa, hints of smoke and wood; as it warms, it takes on a luscious, fruity port-like scent. The flavor is quite rich with caramel and raisin, though it isnt cloyingly sweet. Some roasty notes linger in there, too, as do some dark fruits. There is a rather vinous tone to the whole thing that I like quite a bit. Some vanilla and wood float around, and theres an earthy sweetness to the finish that sticks on the palate for a while. The alcohol is barely detectable, just enough to cut the sweetness. This is some seriously good stuff.
Tap at Capones. Muddy, dark brown with a thin head. Aroma of brown sugar, toffee and dark fruit. Nice fruity finish of black cherry and fig. No smokiness but a great brew.
Firkin at Capones. Starts out with an a fairly intense coffee taste that gives way to a malty toffee flavor. Not bad, but the first half tasted better than the latter portion.

Draft at Capones for the Cigar City tasting with James. Pours a cloudy, apple-cider brown with zero head. Aroma of fine scotch, honey, vanilla, sweet malts, caramel, toffee, and some hops. Medium bodied with a well-rounded, balanced, slightly boozy palate. Finishes cleanly with a bit of a scotch-like warming in the throat and belly. Awesome scotch ale.
UPDATED: MAR 18, 2012 Draft at Capones with Pat. Pours a hazy reddish brown body. Aroma is sweet malts, scotch flavors. Mouthfeel is medium. Notes of sweet malt, and some alcohol.
On tap at Capones. Creamy body.  Dark brown color with tan hues.  Aroma of toffee, hazelnut, cherry.  Flavor has lots of toffee, coffee, toasted malts, and some dark fruit.  Very nice!

Incredible really.  A dark brown ale with a creamy head that comes alive.  Flavors are everywhere--malted milk, toffee, sweet cream, and a bit of warmness from the alcohol, and a hint of hazelnut coffee.  Bomber from IBG.

Bottle at Peters RBSG. Murky brown pour with a nice looking light brown head. Aroma has notes of caramel, vanilla extract, and clove. Its a really well-balanced nose with a nice spice to it. Flavor is bourbon (I guess I should say scotch), brown sugar, and vanilla. I like. I like a lot.

750 mL. Pours a deep, dark brown with a huge, frothy light tan head. The aroma is roasty with lots of earth and coffee along with roast beef, fresh cut wood and nuts. The flavor is sweeter than I anticipated. Its not problematic, but it becomes a bit sticky after finishing off the entire 750. Leathery flavors are here and there along with notes of almonds, molasses, oak and vanilla. Pretty darn decent for a scotch ale. Many in the style can get sticky sweet though. This is no exception.
Deep brown with a decent beige head. Aroma is of chocolate, malt and peat. Taste is of malt and peat.

A-dark brown with reddish hues and quite hazy. the head is a tan color with good retention and thick lace

S-metalic notes blended with an underlying chocolate. toffee after the metalic notes with light dark fruit sweetness. the metalic notes start to fade as it warms and I swirl it

T-lots of chocolate with that metalic note in the mix. a good bit of toffee, notes of scotch. light notes of dark fruits in the back, cherries with a touch of plum. again, the metalic flavors seem to fade in time.

M-extremely smooth and creamy on the palate, good full body and chewy. low carbonation but doesnt fall off.

D-this is pretty tasty as it warms up and the metalic notes fade. nice flavors and everything seems to compliment each other well.

Bottle thanks to JMFG.  Pours a very, very dark reddish brown with a reddish tan head.  Aroma of peat, smoke, dark fruits, brown sugar.  Flavor is big.  Sweet.  Strong.  Lots of toffee, caramel, peat, smoke.  Nice and malty.  Never turns me off with its sweetness though.  Thick and chewy mouthfeel with decent carb and finishes with a wave of coffee.  Pretty awesome brew.
Super dark. Malty. Tons of toffee. Very interesting coffee taste that lingers. This is very interesting for a Scotch Ale. Very different.

750 ml bottle; thanks Scrizzzz; enjoyed this very much before and this time was side by side with the BA version; light reddish brown with bubbly tan head; dark fruits, caramel and brown sugar; light, sticky and quite sweet overall; not quite as blown away as before (rated it a 4.0 the first time), but prefer over the BA version b/c the dark fruits shone more head

Original rating (9/17/09 - 4.0) - 750 ml bottle; thanks BVC!!! pours clear, dark brown with thin tan head; nutty. malty with dark fruit and brown sugar; very up front with the sugars and sweetness; dry finish and malty rich; very yummy; yeasty with plenty of body; not like any other scotch ale ive had and overall very good

Pours dark brown with a hint of red. 1 inch thick creamy head that disapates very slowly. Aroma of cheeries and tootsie rolls. Medium mouthfeel.Toffee with losts of coffee in the finish. Not one of my favorite styles but very well done.

Bottle from Total Wine Ft Lauderdale. Pours out a ruby hued brown color with a small lacing head. Aroma is of sweet toffee, caramel, and a slightly earthy note. Taste is complex, caramel/toffee sweetness, light hop notes, lingering earth, toast, light woodsy note. Overall a solid scotch, but maybe a touch too sweet.

Dark reddish-brown pour with a tan head. Aroma of sweet molasses, dark fruit, cofee. Taste is malty, toasty, little sweet, all-around tasty. great mouthfeel. This is a beer that would match up easily with most food pairings. Nice aftrtaste.

From bottle courtesy of dpjuart. Tootsie Roll, sweet and malty with light fruity hops. Rich aroma, sweet, alcohol. Dark orange-brown clear with thin light tan lacing head. Medium-heavy oily body with medium carbonation. Starts and stays sweet throughout, malty and rich with Tootsie Roll, caramel, brown sugar. Mild alcohol warming. Sticky sweet with lingering sweet tongue in the after. A bit cloying. Nice scotch ale, very tasty.

Trade from tarheels86.  Thanks, man.  What a a great  Scotch Ale.  Pours dark brown with an, one finger head.  Caramel and cherry nose.  Tastes of chocolate covered cherries, caramel, molasses, plum, brown sugar and a touch of honey.  Very complex.

This poured a medium to dark brown color with a very small beige head. Aroma was thick caramel, lightly roasted, and some nuttyness in there too. Flavor was silky smooth, a bit light roasted coffee, darker overrippened fruits, and toffee. A nice blend of flavors in this one.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bottle. Murky brown pour with a monster fluffy light brown head. Long retention. Aroma of toffee and mild coffee. Taste is mild cherry, molasses, and big malt. Easily the best scotch ale I have had.

Bottle from Frank Smiths.  Pours turbid burny umber with a huge, fluffy 3-finger brown head and lace to spare.  Nose is  scotch malty, dark fruity, with notes of fig, toffee, brown sugar, hops, earthy, and cacao.  Tastes rich, malty, somewhat sweet, with figgy and red winey fruit, butterscotch (not diacetyl), brown sugar, molasses, and fine tobacco.  Reminds me a lot of Alesmiths scotch ale,, the name of which escapes me at the moment, and a bit of the original Stoudts scotch ale, which was a masterpiece.  Very complex palate, and as it warms I get more cherry flavor, soime slight funky lactic notes, and tons of malt throughout.  This is an elite scotch ale.

750 ml bottle from the brewery, shared with Nico, Felix and Philip.  Pours dark maroon, medium brown head, decent lacing.  Aroma of licorice, dates, prunes.  Taste has chocolate, licorice, caramel.  Decent stuff.

Bottle @ Papsø. Thanks. Pours dark brown with a small creamy head. Nose is sweet and vinous. coffee, liquorice and caramel. Heavy sweet with lots of toffee and an oaky touch. Full bodied. Ends very dry.

75 cL bottle, courtesy of Papsoe. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is hoppy and roasted malt, slight caramelish. Fruity, hoppy and light caramelish sweet flavoured. Distinct bitterness and mild fruity note into the finish. Rather American take on a scotch ale.

Super big head that takes too long to dissipate. Off white head over deep brown/red brew. Aroma is super sweet and malty, flavor is the same- like malta. Almost too sweet, this sticks around your teeth. Lower flavor score and overall score because its so hard to drink. More like an Aperitif, Im glad I shared the bottle with three other people. Bottle from DRB Miami.
Bottle at Papsø 23-Apr-2010 - Thanks. Cloudy red/brown - white edges. Herbal, tea, roasted, chocolate, berries, fruity, roasted, licorice, smokey notes, red berries.

Bottle at Papsø.
Hazy red brown coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Fruity aroma of caramel and dried fruits with notes of alcohola dn dark chocolate.
Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel and dried fruits with notes of dakr chocolate.
Sweet finish.
Sweet aroma with hard roasted malt, caramel, dark chocolate and coffee notes. Sweet flavour with roasted malt, sweet flavour with roasted malt, dark chocolate and coffee hints. Finished sweet.

Bottled. Dark amber coloured. Unclear. Light brown dense head. aroma of caramel and sweetness. Cocoa, fruits and spice notable. Flavour of caramel, sweetness, cocoa and spice. Medium bodied. Dry light grapy caramel in the end.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2010 cloudy brown, small ligt brown head
nice sweet cookie like fruiy aroma. faint. wood? or is i
t faint dark fruits
flavor is sort of stale hoppy, dark fruity, caramel, toffee, various spicy notes. complex, things to explore - but the initial overall impression is well brewed old beer.
re-rate 2010-09-17 at plovmand tasting
bottled version.
nice woody aroma, spices, very very nice aroma. 8
flavor is dark fruits spices, wood, faint hops,  very complex and very tasty. 8
second tasting of this beer was much better.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of daknole. Pours an opaque dark amber with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel and alcohol. Solid body, caramel, fruit and a little wood. Some warming alcohol in the finish. 230410

bottle poured a brown in color with a one finger dark tan head. aroma has dark fruit, brown sugar, chocolate dipped cherry, roasted malt, and toasted toffee. fairly hefty coating mouth feel with good carbonation. flavor has a lot more roasted malt than expected, peat, fig, prune, molasses, and brown sugar. it gets more peaty and a bit of earthy coffee comes on as the glass progresses definitely some sweetness and a bit of alcohol heat on the finish.

Bottle: Poured a deep brown burgundy color ale with a medium size foamy head with good retention and minimal lacing. Aroma of rich sweet malt with some deep notes of caramel and toffee is enjoyable though very close to the overly sweet territory. Taste is also an enjoyable mix between some rich sweet malt with deep notes toffee and caramelized sugar. Body is quite full with OK carbonation and no apparent alcohol. I usually like some peat malt in my scotch ale but not sure it would have benefited this one since there is so much residual sugar.

Bottle packed to Boise thanks to Ibrew2or3 Pours out a dark brown topped with a small tan head. Aroma is of sweetness pitfruit, light chocolate notes and some rich malts. Taste much as the aroma more of the sweetness a rich malts. A little nut but very light. A tasty one. I wish I would have had this side by side with the BA one.

Pours dark brown with a nice tan head. Nose is roasty, chocolate, and hints of sweetness.  Flavors are full of sweetness, raisin, toffee, roasted malts, and has a nice smoky finish to it. Also nice bitterness at the end. Not much of the alcohol present even though its 8%.  Great beer.

He poured clear browns dark and polished with glints of burnt amber streaking along the edges of my vision. A cappuccino head foams and burbles before settling into a soft comforter of epic snoozing proportions. I tease his depths which leaves a few patches of lace while releasing a massive nose of Scotch Ale delights. Big Sound is right because if a beers nose could declare itself in regalia, this one would be a cacophony delight of horns, trumpets, and bagpipes. Spices announce themselves first with cinnamon, nutmeg, and powdered ginger. As spices dance in selfless delight, a gentle river of licorice babbles nearby. Dried prunes and figs tag along for the ride. A crisp snap in the back is all about candied red apples while that holiday horror, fruitcake, rears its ugly head. In this instance, think of the candied fruits, sugars, and spices that usually accompany this brick of tooth decay. As spices continue to sooth and delight, chili peppers simmer in the background above a slow fire, the old wood embers glowing softly in the low light. Rounding out his richly complex nose is cold burnt chocolates, dark and brittle in the best ways possible. Wow. Talk about a massive nose; an opus of historical note. Wiping the inevitable drool off my chin, I drink deep and long. Rich, full, smooth, creamy, and mouth-coating; if only all first impressions were this satisfying. A long bitter burnt finish rich with bakers and burnt chocolate immediately makes his presence known. A total turn-around from his nose. Dried chili permeates his palate front, center, and back. Exuding gentle warmth, the heat tickles and teases without compromising his scotch ale brethren. Take dried prunes and dates, add blender, push button, and watch-smell-taste as they are pureed into a sticky ooey-gooey mess of dark fruit delights. Old wood still tainted with the essence of earth crackles and chars, the black ash and burnt wood essence perfectly complementing burnt chocolate. His finish is long. Breathing deep once more, cinnamon and nutmeg tinge my breath while long tendrils of ABV weave their way through my chest. As Big Sound slowly warms and my glass slowly diminishes in wealth, I am left with a heart-rending dilemma: I dont want to finish. No, nothing is wrong with my beer; quite the opposite. I dont want to say goodbye, so deliciously profound has this quaffing session been. My heart rends and aches at such cruel realitybut all good beers must come to an end, I suppose. It didnt make it any easier, Ill tell you that.


One of Cigar Citys first brews to see life in bottled-form, Big Sound Scotch Ale was delightfully different and heavenly delicious scotch ale. In comparison with other scotch ales, Big Sound definitely stands on his own, a proud member of his lineage, but resolute in his own independence. A bottle of Big Sound may be hard to come by, but if you should be so lucky, cradle that bottle lovingly against your fast-beating heart all the way home.

Appearance: Pours out an opaque, dark brown body accented with some amber highlights and topped with a half-inch of beige head.

Smell: The aroma is plushly malty, rooted around a concentrated toasty breadiness coated with sweet-scented caramel. This is supported with notes of chocolate, roasty coffee, and a fruitiness that grows even bolder when the beer is given a moment to warm up a bit.

Taste: Deep robust maltiness with a fair amount of soothing sweetness. Tastes of caramelized sugars, toasted bread crusts and, whaddya know, even some chocolate-coated grains and coffee are present, as is a vibrant dried dark fruitiness. Undercurrent of earthiness throughout. Very low, subtle hop bitterness. A bit more breadiness and a touch more roast in the lightly warming finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel.

Drinkability: I certainly enjoyed this one. Sure, its a bit deeper and darker than your usual Scotch Ale, but who gives a crap as long as it makes for a tasty, enjoyable beer.

The aroma is pretty subtle and straight-forward for the style with a big slightly-smoked caramel malt backbone with some dark fruit mixed in.  Hints of molasses and chocolate are in there is well.

A solid pour into my 25cl tulip glass produces a three finger thick, nicely amber tinged, full amber color.  The beer is a dark amber color that has a concentrated redness to it.  When held up to the light the beer shows a nicely concentrated, red, ruby color.  The beer has an interesting note to it up front, it is quite sweet with an almost cinnamon like character to it sweetness; almost reminds me of a deeply caramelized, cinnamon sweetened red-hot.  There is a touch of toasted grain underneath the sweet aroma.  Perhaps this is a bit too cold (though it is at 50ºF / 10ºC), a quick stint in the microwave has me noticing a bit more caramel character rather than straight sweetness, some berry like fruit character as well as more toasted malt character.  Actually the sticky sweetness has now all but disappeared.  The aroma started out a bit on the simplistic side, but it does get a bit better if you really let it warm up, though it still doesnt quite have the complexity that I was hoping for.

This is sweet tasting with a thick, chewy body that easily tames the sweetness, which definitely is not cloying.  The beer finishes with a touch of warming alcohol as well as a chewy, whole grain toastiness, and a deeply caramelized malt character.  A bit of caramelized, marshmallow character is in the middle and the finish has a hint of roast grain that adds just a hint of bite to balance a smidge of the sweetness.  This does have some salty smokiness to it as well, which is quite subtle and I would guess is not from any actual peat smoked malt.  This has a touch of fruitiness to it with mostly a raisin-like note that likely is contributed by the malt character.  While the sweetness is not too much in this warmed up beer, it does still have a candy like note to it with all of the caramelized specialty malt character floating around in this beer.  

In hopes of cutting the sweetness I have taken to eating an overly sweetened brownie, this does tame the beers sweetness, but actually brings a touch of tartness out in the beer.  It does accentuate a touch more of the light roast character, a slight bit more smokiness, as well as bringing out more of the toasted malt character.

Not a bad beer, I must admit that I got a bit too caught up in excitement around this brewery, my expectations of grandeur where probably a bit too much, but I was expecting a lot more from this beer.  It doesnt quite have the complexity and balance that I really want to see in a great example of the style.  Really my biggest complaint here is that the beer has a bit too much sweetness; it does need some sweetness, but if it was a touch drier it would really allow a lot more complex malt character to come through.  A touch more age might round this out a bit though; six months to a year might see this beer peaking.  I am still quite excited to try other beers from this brewery, they seem to be doing some really creative things.

Its reminiscent more of Belhaven Wee Heavy in its flavor profile but with a balancing of hops that keeps the sweetness in check. Rich roasted chocolate up front followed by thick notes of caramel and cherry. Some strong raisin and fig and even a bit of light smoke and leather. Simply AMAZING. The palate is super thick and I was amazed this was only 8.5% not because of the alcohol which is non existant, but because the palate is just insanely full. Massive body. Chewy and rich. I actually may like this more than the Zhukovs Impy Stout! Insane props to Joey and Wayne on this amazing masterpiece.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2009 750 mL bottle from Lees Liquors in Orlando (big thanks to Austin for getting this one).  Pours dark brown with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, smoke, and very light piney hops.  Very good, balanced flavor; not too sweet like many Scotch Ales.  This does have some characterisitics of an imperial stout with the smoked flavors, toffee, and a hint of coffee.  I said this in my review of Founders Dirty Bastard but I now have to ammend that review: best Scotch Ale I have had.  This time, I dont think its even close.  Phenomenal beer.
Murky chestnut with a light head.  Earthy nose is toffee and caramel richness.  Soft, full, rich mouthfeel.  Soft, chewy toffee notes, very sweet and lush.  Hints of peat and wood.  Well-balanced.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2012 Bottle shared by Daknole. Dark brown with fizzy golden tan/cappuccino head. Sweet toffee, caramel, custard, coffee ice cream aromas. Smooth and very creamy. Nice warmth. Not smokey but more of the sweet scotch flavors, candi sugar, fruity with tons of raisin character. Super smooth in spite of being sweet.

Bottle sent to my by tpd975.  Great great scotch ale.  Very dark brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma is full of great caramel malt, nuts, fruit and some brown sugar.  The body of this beer is beyond amazing.  Coats the mouth like very few beers can dream of.  The flavor is just loaded with every imaginalbe malt flavor you can name.  Caramel, toffee, fruit, vanilla, chocolate, wood, roast, brown sugar, man oh man.  Wayne and Joey are seriously cranking out some amazing beers.  but what do I know, I am just a homer.

Pours a dark brown almost opaque with medium tan head.  Aromas of peat and roasted malts.  Flavors of caramel, coffee, dark fruit and malty goodness.  Nice thick and creamy on the palate with a slightly bitter finish.  Well done Wayne and Joey.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2010 A: Pours a very dark amber almost black hue. The head was a full one finger of mocha goodness. Okay retention with a nice smattering of lace.

S: Mmmmm this is what malt goodness smells like. This one oozes caramel, toffee, molasses, and dark brown sugar. Hints of chocolate hide beneath this malt mountain along with a touch of dark fruit.

T: Wow I hate to feel like a homer everytime I crack a CCB, but to be honest there are very few if anyone doing what they do. This beer is packed with flavor. The sweet malt goodness is off the scale. Tons of brown sugar and gooey caramel. Touches of molasses and nuts. There is a nice dose of chocolate with notes of dark fruits. A bit or earth and a dash of deep roasted malt round things out. This is an Imperial Scotch Ale that is in a class that only includes AleSmith Wee Heavy.

M: Rather full in body for the style. Smooth, Rich, Bold, Awesome!

D: Great I consumed an entire 750ml and pondered opening another. Alas I will save it for another day. It checks in at over 9% ABV this year so this is one that can hang around for awhile.

Wayne and Joe does it again. I bow to your greatness :)
Bottle, thanks to Daknole. Pours dark brown, with a tan head. Aroma is malt, coffee, and caramel. Flavor is caramel, coffee, malt, and a little fruit. Medium body. Nicely done.

Bottle,I picked this up at Knightly in Orlando and glad i did,it poured a very dark brown to black with a nice thick tan head,taste of caramel and roasted malts with a toffee finish in the end,alcohol is well hidden but as it warmed it was noticeable but that was good thing,this was very drinkable and i look forward to CCB beers in the future .CHEERS1

Had it on draft at Redlight Redlight.  Pours an opaque brown-black with a small creamy tan-white head.  The aroma is roasted malt with a hint of coffee.  The roasty taste combines with a hint of dark fruit sweetness that gives way to a rich, smooth finish underlined with the essence of cocoa, coffee, and maybe a little toast.  Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth with light carbonation.  This was my first Scotch Ale and I was very pleased!

Bottle.  Pours dark reddish brown with a thick beige head.  Aroma is of deep roasted malt, caramel, light smoke and some coffee.  Flavor is big roasted caramel malt and toffee, some bread and slight currant undertones are also present.  Totally devoid of peat.  Very rich but still very drinkable, slight bitter finish.

(Rating #5000) BottleThis beer rocks!... Pours too dark and murky to see through  Id say burnt caramel with a small, creamy, off-white head. Good retention. The aroma is a luxurious, odd mix of singed caramel, smoke, tobacco and a gob of charred marshmallow. Tough to figure out, but very nice. Full-bodied with a creamy/sticky mouthfeel and ticklish carbonation. The flavor is a swirl of all things sweet, caramelized, singed and toasted  espresso, chocolate, caramel and toffee. Finishes sweet and rich and leaves me wanting to pop the top on another bottle immediately. Quickly! Im hooked and need my next fix.

Bottle. Poured a ruby brown with a medium richly beige head. Appeared low in carbonation on the pour.  Really big melanoidin nose, full of caramel, toffee and that weird vinous grapiness I get in the most melanoidined out beers. Full mouthfeel with notes of smoke and caramel, yielding to some chocolate and coffee in the middle. Carbonation is appropriately low, so this big soft mouthfeel comes from the richness of the malts. Theres a melange of fruitiness in this. Theres a bit of alcohol warmth on the finish but its well displayed alongside the malts. This is a sipper due to its richness.

0.75L bottle pours deep mahogany with clear amber to rose edges and full tan head. The initial aroma as the pours ends is a pulse of cherries. Upon further inspection I get more cherries, faint dark grape jam mixing with a growing cornucopia of malts like biscuit, melanoidin, caramunich, toffee and other notes I cant put my finger on . . . maybe chicory too. The taste starts smooth and sweet moving toward increasing levels of roasted maltiness. But first I get cherries and toffee mixing with a brief pulse of dark grape jam. Then an array of malts descend on the palate jabbing away with toffee, biscuit, melanoidin, more toffee and malt roastiness. Beyond midway coffee and chicory goodness enter and help bring the dark fruitiness and malts toward the finish. It ends with chocolate, chicory, faint dark roasted coffee beans, figs, cherries, toffee and mildly drying roasted malts. This brew has tons and tons of flavor and is a bit much for one person (me) to finish off a big bottle.

Draft at Redlight Redlight. This one pours a hazy, dark brown color with a small, foamy cream colored head. The head settles leaving rings of lacing around the glass. The aroma is really rich and malty with toffee and caramel coming forward to go with hints of dark fruits, roast, and some earthy hops. The flavor follows the rich malt theme with sweet toffee and creamy caramel coming first to go with some figs and stewed raisins. There is a slight hint of cherry in there as well. Some cocoa and roasted coffee come through to balance out the fruit sweetness. Toasted malts and earthy hops bring nice bitterss on the backend and tie everything togethe nicely. The mouthfeel is full and very creamy with a lingering roasty finish and a touch of the alcohol warmth. This is a big, rich, and malty scotch ale with great flavors and complexity. Really well done. I would love to see what some smoked peat would add.

I have been looking forward to trying this one for a while! 75cl bottle from Whole Foods (Tampa, FL). Pours a murky, muddy, dark brown to black with one finger tan/cinnamon head that settles slowly. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of roast, caramel, raisins, figs, some hints of cocoa. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of toffee, light roast, caramel, figs, raisins, cocoa, dark ripe fruits, some hints of earthiness and cream. Generally medium to full body with a pleasing syrupy, malty finish.

Pours a murky brown/black. Thin tan head. Nose is initially boozey then roasty as hell. sweet caramel nose. Flavor is a wonderful alcoholic malt bomb. Roasty, dark fruits, some charred flavor. Mouthfeel is very full, slightly oily. Very very smooth. Drink this one on the warmer side to let the alcohol come out. Beautiful. Incredible scotch ale.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2009 Murky, foggy brown body with creamy mocha head.  Roasty, Toasty malt with caramel notes and toffee on the nose sweet fruit mild chocolate and bright finish.  the bottle fermentation gives the beer a soft and subtle mouth feel.  All around solid.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2009 Draft at Redlight Redlight. A dark, chewy looking, muddy brown body is crowned by a small layer of creamy, khaki colored foam. Thin, broken, frosted glass sheeting coats the glass well. The nose is really rich and malty, showing a huge nougat component, stewed raisin, medium-dark cocoa, caramel, figs, and sweet, dark cherries. Theres a good deal of barley roast going on as well, which brings a nice earthiness into the fold. Flavors follow suit, rich nougat, and caramel leading the charge.  A bevy of dark, stewed fruits lend sweet complexities, fig and raisin showing strongest. Again, rich barley and cocoa roast bring an earthy, toasty balance to all the fruity sweetness. The mouthfeel is full and lush, very creamy, finishing with some alcohol warmth and lingering roast. A bit of stickiness is all that holds it back. Joey and Wayne were shooting for an ultra-malty, rich, imperial wee heavy, and I would say they passed with flying colors. A little smoked peat would put this over the edge.

draft @ redlight redlight.  Rich toffee and caramel malt aromas.  Pours a cloudy rich brown color with a thick off white head.  Rich malt flavors, toffee, caramel with hints of darker molasses and dark fruits like caramelized figs and smoked dates in the flavor.  Very smooth beer.

Draft @ redlight redlight. Pours a deep murky, ruddy brown with a creamy tan head. Some nice lacing. Big malty scotch ale, not peaty, but complex with dark fruits, some chocolate roast, that doppelbock malt midrange, brown sugar and a touch of the alcohol coming through as it warms. Lush mouthfeel, low carbonation, a bit drying at the finish from the alcohol.

Bottle thanks to Wayne.  Pours a slightly hazy brown with a tan head.  Nose is sweet malt, caramel, some maple sweetmess.  Taste is malt everywhere with caramel/ toffee sweetness, and some smoke with a tiny amount of hops to level off this masterpiece.  Very nice, medium-bodied beer that leaves nice lacing.

Bottle courtesy of Wayne. Pours a slightly hazy dark brown with amber highlights with a one finger light tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of sweet malts, caramel, with toasted and light roasted malts in the background. Taste is lots of malt with a drying roasty toasty finish. Medium mouthfeel with a mild a mount of bitterness and medium soft carbonation. A damn fine beer.

Draft at Redlight.  Pours a cloudy dark brown color with a thick tan head.  Aroma is full of malts and caramel, with a nice roast.  Flavor has a huge malt, with the same toasted characteristics that make the Cigar City brown ales so delicious.  I dont know if it is simply the freshness or not, but I love that flavor.  The rich malt and toast leads into a slightly smokey finish with a little bit of hops popping up in there.  I cant believe this is packing 8.5-9%ABV.  It is hidden well.

On tap @ Redlight.  Hazy dark amber color with a medium broken light khaki head.  Aroma is mostly rich sweet caramel, but a slight earthen character is present.  The taste is more distinct, with a rich sweetness that isnt overbearing, some toffee and toasted grains, and the balance of some earthy hops that is welcome.  Im very picky about my Scotch ales, and usually require a hint of peat or smoke to put a Scotch at a 4 or above, but this one uses the malt richness so well.
